149513703.review:
[h1] Incredibly Fun and Addictive RPG Adventure! [/h1]
[h2] Rating: ★★★★★ (5/5) [/h2] 



I recently played Epic Battle Fantasy 3 on Steam and I have to say, I absolutely loved it. The game is a perfect combination turn-based battles, strategic thinking, and a whimsical sense of humor.

The graphics in the game are stunning, with beautifully detailed backgrounds and intricate character designs. The animations are smooth and fluid, making each battle feel like a spectacle. The attention to detail is evident throughout the game, from the intricate spell effects to the humorous expressions of the characters.

The gameplay is addictive and engaging. The battles are challenging but not overly difficult, allowing for a perfect balance of strategy and fun. There are numerous skills and abilities to unlock and upgrade, giving players a sense of progression and making each battle feel different and rewarding.

I also enjoyed the variety of enemies and bosses in the game. Each enemy has different strengths and weaknesses, forcing players to think strategically and plan their attacks accordingly. The boss battles are particularly exciting, with epic showdowns that require careful planning and execution.

One aspect of the game that really stood out to me was the sense of humor. The dialogue is filled with witty banter and pop culture references, making me laugh out loud several times. The characters themselves are quirky and endearing, each with their own distinct personalities.

Overall, Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a fantastic game that I would highly recommend to anyone who enjoys turn-based RPGs. The stunning graphics, engaging gameplay, and hilarious dialogue make it a truly memorable experience. I can't wait to see what the developers come up with next.

Full of childhood nostalgia, the same frustrations with the cosmic monolith, three times the charm with three heads on the dragon, and the long haul battle with Akron. 

One of those games that you complete over two or three days, with siblings coming in and out of your room and going "hey I remember this scene" and damn the medals that are absolutely iconic. 

The jokes are still quite funny - Natalie is still incredibly cute. Time to play it all again, on hard, then on epic! Each time the fun of opening all the chests remains. Really a timeless classic. 

What I don't like so much - you tend to get the equipment that is most useful in the region, e.g. hunting in the cold for fur for the fur sets and then you're done by the time you finish grinding. That said, it's not meant to be forced on Normal! Sometimes you're just stubborn. I had to grind the hard way at the end to deal with the cosmic monolith opening. ^o^ Happy playing, you won't regret spending your afternoon on it.

141560007.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a delightful and nostalgic RPG adventure that pays homage to classic turn-based combat games while injecting its own unique charm. The game follows the heroic trio of Matt, a brave and determined swordsman, Natalie, a clever and resourceful magician, and Lance, a laid-back and skilled gunman. These characters embody classic RPG tropes, with Matt as the valiant knight, Natalie as the powerful mage, and Lance as the cool and aloof rogue.

The gameplay in Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a perfect blend of strategic combat and exploration. Players can unleash a variety of flashy and devastating attacks, summon powerful creatures to aid them in battle, and customize their characters with a wide range of equipment and skills. The game also features challenging boss battles, hidden treasures, and quests that keep the adventure engaging and rewarding.

What sets Epic Battle Fantasy 3 apart is its delightful sense of humor and quirky references. The game is filled with witty dialogue, amusing interactions, and clever nods to popular culture and gaming tropes. From battling absurd enemies like giant cats and penguins to encountering hilarious NPCs, the game constantly surprises and entertains with its lighthearted tone.

The visuals in Epic Battle Fantasy 3 are charmingly retro, with colorful pixel art that captures the essence of classic RPGs. The music is catchy and nostalgic, complementing the gameplay and adding to the overall immersive experience.

Overall, Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a must-play for fans of classic RPGs. With its lovable characters, engaging gameplay, and humorous references, it offers a delightful and entertaining journey that will leave players craving for more epic battles and adventures.

141347485.review:
It's Free. It's Fun. It's the turning point for a classic series of flashgames.

I was never a fan of ebf 1 or 2, but the overworld, customization of abilities and equipment, fun npc character writing, and clever little hidden chests which ebf 3 adds to the series really turned things around for me.

The battle system is much more engaging and fine tuned that what is standard for most jrps. Your team heals between battles so the dev wasn't afraid to make each battle its own event. You'll use all sorts of combinations of elemental abilities and teamwork between party members to clear out foes.

It's cute, it's fun, and it's creative (why are you reading this? it's fee). If you like it I recommend you check out ebf 4 & 5 as well.

138643598.review:
A classic flash game from my childhood and brings some of the best that world had to offer. EBF 3 is a fantastic game and was so much fun to play through and finally beat since I couldn't do it as a little kid. Everything about this game just....works. The art style holds up even to today's standards and fits wonderfully. The music oh god the music is so good and I found myself just humming away at it while exploring what the game had to offer. The characters you have are amusing and I found myself liking all 3 of them. The humor in the game is pretty funny and doesn't get on my nerves like it does in a lot of other games. The game doesn't take itself seriously and that's something I absolutely love about it. Easily a top 3 flash game behind Raze and SFH and I'd highly recommend anyone who hasn't played it to check it out!

The combat in this game is simplistic yet it works perfectly. There are a wide range of moves and builds you can utilize depending on the region. Hunting for items and components to upgrade them is fun and doesn't feel annoying in the slightest. The elemental system of combat is something I quite enjoyed especially since there are a wide variety of elements you can use. Almost all of the abilities feel useful in some way shape or form. A wide variety of opponents keeps the game fresh as you jump from world to world. The enemies aren't a joke either, especially further into the game and on higher difficulties. In the last two worlds and ESPECIALLY the bosses, the enemies will brutalize you for making one mistake on the harder difficulties and you'll have to restart. That said, the game doesn't feel unfair to play with the exception of the MONOLITHS and the reaper strike some of the World 5 enemies do. Getting instakilled based on RNG is irritating and the monoliths are a little overtuned in my opinion, especially if you are playing blind and not expecting them.

All in all, this game is fantastic. I can't wait to try the 4th and 5th one since I've heard they are even better than this one and this one was super fun. Killing that last boss was so satisfying. If you haven't, please play this game. It's so good.

Final Grade: 9/10 - A Crown Jewel of the Flash World

132483956.review:
[h1]FREE JRPG!? Don't mind me, I've already hooked[/h1]
"Epic Battle Fantasy 3" is a silly turn-based JRPG (Japanese role-playing game) that is sure to bring a smile to your face! With full of useless NPCs, rabid cats, childish humor, unreasonably large weapons, anime-style character designs, and other nonsensical elements, this game is a delightful and quirky adventure.

What makes this game even more special is that it's totally free! You can spend hours upon hours exploring the game's vibrant world and battling monsters, all without spending a single penny.

What's a RPG game without hours of grinding? Farming the same monster for that specific loot? You can go crazy in this game, also mindless revisiting ALL previous map for hidden paths and treasures...

I've personally played this game for over 28.9 hours and I can say that it never gets old. The humor is always fresh and the battles are always challenging. The game's art style is colorful and eye-catching, and the weapons and other equipment are just plain fun to look at.

If you're a fan of turn-based RPGs and don't mind a little bit of silly humor, then "Epic Battle Fantasy 3" is definitely worth checking out. I hope the developers continue to make more sequels because I can't get enough of this fun and quirky game!

In conclusion, this game is suitable for players of all ages and offers hours of enjoyable gameplay. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a unique and lighthearted gaming experience.

130811109.review:
Positives:
-Art style is unique and distinct in its own way; its minimalistic art style captures that feeling of an indie dev creating ocs/worlds from scratch. It's charm is nostalglic.
-Captures the essence of JRPGs in terms of world building and gameplay. Progressing new levels feels exciting as you encounter new enemies, obtain new abilities, finding new equipment, meet new NPCS, etc. 
-Turn-based combat is reminiscent of other JRPGs (hp/mp bars, skills, elemental spells, special moves, items, etc).
-Difficulty is challenging. Enemies come in hordes and hit harder as you progress the game.
-Exploration is encouraged. Treasure chests are hidden very well in every nook and cranny of every stage.
-Writing is fun and quirky. Characters are filled to the brim with funny dialogue. Which motivated me to talk to every NPC in the game, as well as progressing the game.
-Free.
-Natalie. 

Negatives:
-Progression is repetitive; defeat enemies blocking the way, go to the next room, fight more enemies, reach the boss, defeat boss, defeat enemies blocking the way, repeat.
-Enemies feel like bullet sponges. Takes centuries to defeat them (even with super effective damage).
-Some achievements don't work. Found all the chest in the ice stage and never got a medal for it.

8/10

This is one of the best JRPG's you will come across for millennia. Bouncy titties, Suspicious tentacles, Morbid demons, it has it all. The overused concept of turn-based combat is used brilliantly, providing strategy, balanced fights, and most importantly; fun. This, as another review has stated, is "A love letter to 90's and early 2000's anime." This game has an engaging, and soothing soundtrack that you can easily enjoy without much attention paid to it. Along with these beautiful displays of gaming, it makes you think outside the box, focusing on what is best, and upgrading them as much as you can, strategizing every step you make. With simple, yet complex art, a balanced yet optionally cruel combat system, and engaging battles, this is one of the best, if not THE best, old games I used to play in my childhood, now revisited with a better mind. I have pressured not 2, not 3, but FOUR people into getting this game, and playing it. With that, my life is truly fulfilled, as I shall profoundly bask in the glory of knowing I have spread my knowledge and tactics to others.

(this is actually a really good game though)

A love letter to 90s and early 2000s anime, with probably the best turn-based combat of its time. (some games have usurped it since then, but not many)

It's obviously much smaller and less grandiose than EBF4 or 5, but I kind of prefer it for that. In some ways, the sequels seem a little too big for their britches; EBF3 is much less dramatic, but it's very well done. I love to load up my save file and just fight the final boss again. No matter how many times I do it, I never know for sure if I'll win or lose on any given attempt.

This game gets my very rare "Actual Good Turn-Based Combat" award, one of only a dozen or so games to do so. Don't miss it!

Having gone through and played on Epic difficulty this cult classic of a flash game, I can safely say that it holds up surprisingly well to modern standards. The jokes still feel relative despite being somewhat dated, and it clearly leans into its game parody of Final Fantasy and other JRPG's just enough without getting in the way of the core game play. While modestly repetitive, it's still a solid turn based RPG that offers the player unique flexibility on how they want to play and offers unique challenges with elements and character strengths and weaknesses.

The best part about all of this is the game is free. A good 10 hours or less it should take you to 100% on Epic difficulty.

101306343.review:
Disclaimer: I'm a fan of the series so my review may be bias. I've played EBF 1 through 4.

It has elements of classic JRPG's without some of the headaches. There's no random encounters, there's no extra grinding needed (assuming you fight every opponent you come across), and you can save anywhere (there's no save points). The game feels pretty balanced to me; the only time i felt caught off-guard was in the areas you unlock through medals and maybe a couple bosses. The opponents are fairly varied and require more strategy as you head deeper in the game.

However, it's not without problems.
[list]
    [*]It's made in Flash and the performance can really drop no matter how strong your machine is. Flash was just never good at performance.
    [*]The controls are a bit dated. You can't click to move but you'll likely prefer to use your mouse in combat so you might be switching between keyboard and mouse all the time. Not a big deal though, and you get used to it.
    [*]There's a lot of different armors, weapons, hats, and skills but i found no reason to use most of them. It's always cool to have a lot of options, but i didn't think they were very useful options.
[/list]

Overall i recommend it. It's free so the worst you can do is waste your time.

99755407.review:
Who would have thought that one of the best JRPGs ever can be obtained and played for free?

Seriously, combat gameplay and general game balance and pacing are perfect. The combat mechanics are pretty straightforward, yet they have enough complexity to make every fight interesting, and it allows for multiple choices and strategies. There are no fights that you would want to win by spamming "attack", practically every encounter is challenging enough for a player who leveled normally, there's no stuff like random encounters, every fight has a unique composition, and you can even skip the majority of encounters, since most of them are optional, though you would have to grind levels somewhere else. If you play the game normally by winning every battle once, you will reach the max level, unlock all skills and upgrade most of your equipment, so there's no need to grind except to upgrade the remaining few articles of clothing, and even that should not take more than 20 minutes.
The gameplay culminates in one of the best final bosses in JRPGs - you're not gonna be defeating him by spamming the knights of the round table, let me tell you that. It makes you use everything you've learnt about the game, while the best final boss music is blasting from your sound device of choice

Graphically, modern JRPGs either fully embraced 3D, or doubled down on nostalgia by making the graphics look like the 4th generation of consoles and by using static sprites. So here is a beautiful 2D game where every character or foe, as well as their attacks and skills, are animated, and every piece of equipment is visibly represented on your characters. The art style is inspired by anime, but is deliberately distinct and unique, so even if you have an aversion towards weaboo stuff (like I had when I first saw the game on Armor Games), give it a chance, it really has a different flavor.

The only thing that can be faulted about this game is that there's practically no plot. The plot is a mere subtext for you to travel through the world and beat the obstacles on your path, but I personally would not take it any other way, it kinda helps the general lighthearted yet black-comedic mood, and makes the fourth wall jokes funny instead of grating.

Oh yeah, and also minigames are lame

98172031.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy, as a series, will always have a special part in my heart. It never ceased to amaze me, and I always wanted to keep playing it, defeating more and more powerful foes and listening to the brilliant soundtrack. But enough of the nostalgia - let's focus on EBF3. This game is where, in my opinion, the series took off. 

At it's core, it is a JRPG turn-based game. It features 3 playble characters as seen in the screenshots - Matt, Natalie and Lance. I won't say that it's a very deep game gameplay wise, but depth is present. It's not just about spamming any attack - enemies have resistance to certain elements, so they will take way less damage, sometimes even zero. On the other hand, they have weaknesses too - you can deal extra damage. Same applies to your characters as well. 

There are plenty of skills for each character. You can summon rain of giants swords upon your enemy, make a giant black hole, or even launch a nuclear missille.

As opposed to its predecessor, EBF2, this game features an open world. There are 6 different areas in total, each has its own theme. You progress from a peaceful forest town with slimes and bushes to space with cosmic monoliths and dragons. Wild, right?

The story is there, but it isn't the game's focus. It's about 3 adventurers saving the world from the old evil that has awakened and wreaked havoc in the world. It's filled with humour and a lot of references, so if you are a fan of serious settings, you wouldn't enjoy this as much.

Visually, graphics are not bad for a flash game made in 2010. It has overall cartoonish style, but art in combat is great, skills and equipment are detailed. The UI can seem a bit weird to use.

The soundtrack is great, it always fits the area it is playing in. I think it has the most iconic songs of the series, for example "You'll never guess this!", " Wings" or "Estavius". The main menu greets you with "That Which We Have Lost And Forgotten" and, in my opinion, that's the most beautiful song in all of EBF.

Overall, this is a wonderful game and I would absolutely recommend it to any fan of RPG games.

97182738.review:
This game does not really hold a candle to its succesors (EBF4 and EBF5, which are exponentially better), but a still fun turn based RPG. Cons:
1) Impossible to remove statuses from foes (like poison)
2) Impossible to counter debuffs without buffing
3) No stat shops
4) Random endgame enemies doing more damage than the boss
5) Resistance percentage to elements/stats not shown
6) Actual stat values (post buff/debuff) being not shown
7) No magic attack for Matt (Screamer counts I guess) and Skull Ghosts being immune to physical damage (I really like Matt okay?)
8) No clear indication whether some skills are physical or magical.
9) No in-game difficulty change/party order change (so berserked players always go first)

Pros:
1) Still humorous and engaging combat
2) Pyrohydra and Akron forcing you to strategize hard (Unless you cheese using evasion builds)
3) Puzzles
4) Achievements giving more gear (Why this was removed from EBF4, I wonder?)

Overall, a solid 8/10 (9/10 considering its free) game but not 9.5/10 or 10/10 like its successors

Epic Battle Fantasy has always been a game dear to my heart. One of the first games I ever played on the internet, it holds up as a fun and cheeky take on the JRPG genre. While the first two are focused solely on combat, and the fourth's artstyle turned many away from the series, EBF3 stands as a favourite for me. It's exploration, puzzles, and fairly long story have kept me coming back to the series time and time again. 

While it certainly has it's missteps and doesn't exactly age as well as one might hope, it's feeling of goofy fun and early modern gaming nostalgia make it a title to remember. I suggest grabbing it up and trying it out. You won't regret it, especially considering it's low price.

93816774.review:
I don't have many criticisms of this game. The gameplay is fluid and well built, with a depth of strategy that you don't often see in these kinds of lightweight games. The variation in difficulty is a nice touch, making the game accessible to players of all ages and skill levels. The cute, cartoonish graphics, humour, and pop-culture references scattered throughout the game are a lovely touch, and I almost can't fault this game,

There's also the typical crazy hard option, and this is actually where my main complaint lies. I actually tend to appreciate super-hard games, and I have completed this game on all difficulties except for easy. The epic difficulty has one fatal flaw. I don't mind if a failure to strategise effectively, or just downright stupid mistakes get me killed in a game. What I do mind is when success comes almost entirely down to luck. I write this on a replay off the game on Epic difficulty, where my entire party has been downed in a single round (despite starting with full health and auto-life) after about an hour of fighting the game's final boss.

All things considered, this is definitely a 10/10 game, but what seems to boil down to poor balancing makes epic difficulty an infuriating process where strategy and sensible gameplay get trumped by simple luck.

92142674.review:
TLDR: It's beautifully designed, has rock solid gameplay, and it's completely free.

A very enjoyable romp in RPG land. The graphics are clean, bright, beautiful, imaginative, and very well animated. The game play is rock solid with unique upgradeable gear and weapons that can change the character's role depending on what's equipped and can be switched out mid-battle.. The player characters are enjoyable and likeable.

Lots of hidden areas, scavenger type side quests, and mini-games.

There's a few cons, sure. Scavenger type side quests means a lot of grinding for the drops necessary to complete them. But for the most part they are optional. 

Grinding, however, is not, as the mobs in each new bite-sized area you enter are of higher level than the previous, And each area is very tiny, with about two to four battles per area. And weapon/armor upgrades require rarer and more numerous item drops. So there is grinding involved, both in leveling up for further areas and keeping your gear upgraded for the battles ahead.

There's a quest log showing who wants what, but no notations of where you met them. 

Some areas and player abilities are locked with no explanation of what you need to unlock them, so you will be referring to guides on occasion.

But none of the cons are game or immersion breaking. It's still a solid game and it's totally free, With that, all complaints are pretty much out the window anyway. And I am enjoying it so much that buying the others in the series was a no-brainer.

90750705.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a solidly designed JRPG with very... mid-2000s Gaia Online aesthetics and story, featuring three "heroes" on a quest to save the world from some sort of giant demon. Mechanically, it's quite a good game, with all three of the heroes having unique skill lists and interesting equipment choices, and certain encounters - mostly the bosses, but also some of the on-map encounters - being fairly difficult, especially on the higher difficulties of Hard and Epic.

On the other hand, the story and characters are... uh... well, it's pretty clear what you're getting from the store screenshots, honestly. If you mostly play these games for the story and don't really care about the mechanics at all, I wouldn't blame you for passing this one up, unless your nostalgia for 2000s anime fandom is quite strong.

Given that Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is both a mechanically solid game and free, it's going to get a strong recommendation from me. You don't really stand to lose out on much but a little bit of your time if it doesn't appeal to you.

(For the record, I played on Hard.)

I love this game so much! There really isn't much else I can say about it, but I'll try
Pros: The music and artstyle is wonderful in my opinion, lots of work and love went into it
Easy to get into, progression isn't very grindy at all actually, you'll reach max level by the final boss, don't worry about that
Mixing and matching equipment can be really fun and you might find something is really effective!
Different difficulties for anyone, whether this is your first rpg or you're an avid rpg player there's something for everyone, I recommend Epic difficulty for sure if you think you've got what it takes!
Cons: Sometimes there can be a definite lack of information concerning what enemies do, and some enemies can be totally unfair at times
There aren't any actual water skills barring items and equip casts, and only 2 wind skills, so it's a tad difficult to exploit those sorts of weaknesses...
Overall I really really like this game, I basically grew up on this whole series of games by Matt, and they've all been very fun. I definitely recommend this to just about anyone.

81164661.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a solidly designed JRPG with very... mid-2000s Gaia Online aesthetics and story, featuring three "heroes" on a quest to save the world from some sort of giant demon. Mechanically, it's quite a good game, with all three of the heroes having unique skill lists and interesting equipment choices, and certain encounters - mostly the bosses, but also some of the on-map encounters - being fairly difficult, especially on the higher difficulties of Hard and Epic.

On the other hand, the story and characters are... uh... well, it's pretty clear what you're getting from the store screenshots, honestly. If you mostly play these games for the story and don't really care about the mechanics at all, I wouldn't blame you for passing this one up, unless your nostalgia for 2000s anime fandom is quite strong.

Given that Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is both a mechanically solid game and free, it's going to get a strong recommendation from me. You don't really stand to lose out on much but a little bit of your time if it doesn't appeal to you.

(For the record, I played on Hard.)

81160759.review:
While this game is incredibly nostalgic from that era of flash games that defined a part of my childhood, it is a great game on its own merit.  Chronologically considering the series, this game, by far, is more more complex, larger scale, and just generally more fun than the two prior games.

The expansion of the combat system, molding it to be more intuitive and uniform, was essential.  The myriad of skills was nice, although one can discern this as the predecessor to the fourth and fifth games, where the options are even more vast and every skill fills more of a niche (lots of overlapping skills and lacking of others).  The transition to more of a JRPG format was surprising, but it made this my go-to when I was young over the previous games simply because it felt rewarding to slowly uncover the map and upgrade equipment — progress could be made and it became less of a linear arcade game.  The sheer amount of unique enemies and good designs for bosses made it interesting to make this progression through the different areas.

As the series is known for, the dialogue is very self-aware.  It satirizes RPG tropes, alludes to pop culture, and makes pretty overt innuendos at every opportunity.  This is what makes the game lovable though.  It does not pretend to have some archetypal fantasy lore that immerses the player; it has about the same vibe as any other flash game from the 2000s.

EBF3 is not as polished as the fourth game, and it certainly is nowhere near as polished as the fifth.  However, the unpolished quality is nostalgic and adds to the attitude the game has about itself (which is why I find this game more fun than EBF4 — hot take).  This simultaneously feels like a flash game and does not feel like a flash game, and to accomplish something like that means a lot of work was put in.  And the game is even free!  No reason to not give it a try.

76725341.review:
I'm not quite done yet beating this game on Epic but I'm getting there, so I figured why not review this game.
Quick note - EBF1 and 2 aren't exactly good representatives of the series, as they're much more like battle gauntlets than proper RPGs - go out and find them online if you really wanna see what I mean.

General pros:
+ Achievements and logging monsters in your bestiary are pretty much completely separate from your actual saves; if you scan a monster but then game over/TPK afterward without saving, the game remembers that you scanned it and keeps it logged for future reference, making your life more convenient and even just a bit more manageable as that's one more character turn that you get to work with on subsequent attempts at whatever encounter you died at.
+ Combat's pretty solid; Rather than working like FF1-3 where you set your team's actions and then turn order processes based on speed, instead, the selected character carries out the action immediately after you set it, so their turn order is entirely up to you how it goes (using one of the things in the Tactics section of the combat menu). Monsters always go top to bottom.
+ Even your starting equipment can be relevant in the end-game as rather than providing a flat ATK/DEF boost, they multiply the character's base stats by given percentages; they also provide varying degrees of extra resistance to elements/status ailments (heck, one can [i]absorb[/i] damage and heal if their resistance to a given element is over 100%) and have extra casting effects sometimes as you upgrade them (such as the White Mage Dress auto-casting Regen on the party at random at high tiers).
+ There's some bonus content depending on how far along you are with achievements - in a few cases, you can actually get bonus items/equipment! (Although these are often guarded by encounters significantly tougher than the average encounter for the area you're in.)
+ This game takes tropes often seen in more well-known RPGs and uses them to great advantage. What's not to love about parodying such things?
+ > There's a lot of humor and references in this game, but I don't imagine that a lot of it's aged particularly well over the years. Ranging from something as tame and blatant as a Dragonball Z reference to... well, I'd be referring to one of the end-game monsters if I were to talk about the other end of the spectrum.
+ Game's perfectly free; No DLC or anything, so you're only losing time if you end up not liking the game. EBF4 and 5 also have free online versions like 3 does, but you don't immediately get some of the content with 4 and 5's online versions.
+ KITTENS! Except you have to fight them. BUT SOME ARE RIDING MECHANICAL HORSES THAT THEY THEMSELVES BUILT! But you also have to fight those. WELL THEY'RE ALL STILL CUTE!
+ The music is always a frickin banger, nuff said.

General cons:
- A more mild con is that EBF3's unpolished when compared to 4 and 5, but the art-style and animation are still wonderful.
- The story's about as close to an excuse plot as you're gonna get while still keeping it relevant (literally, monster screws your team over and leaves them back to square one with the bare essentials to do things, time to get back at the thing) while 4 and 5 have more proper stories, but I think it's really part of the parody-ness of the game.
- Whole-heartedly, don't expect like a 445-hour experience trying to 100% this game, it's more or less about 10-15 hours long. (Giving a range as how much time you take to beat the main game alone can easily vary based on the difficulty you're playing on.)
- > On the topic of difficulty, this game can and [i]will[/i] absolutely wreck you on the Epic difficulty (monsters deal 160% of their normal damage and they also get assorted bonuses). I'm certain the game was more balanced with Normal mode in mind, so select Epic at your own risk.
- Someone said this too so I may as well echo it; Cosmic Monoliths exist in the end-game (I've already felled one so far) and trust me, they're about as deadly as they might sound by the name, their opening attack's animation just [b]e x u d e s[/b] power. Brace for pain and some extremely close scrapes with these things.

With all that said, give this game a whirl if you want! Maybe read some other reviews and get a general consensus first.

71653095.review:
TLDR: Get it, it's free, you have literally nothing to lose.

Size: The game is pretty small, it'll probably take you 5 -10 hours to finish, though it'll take a lot more to get everything. (I don't recommend going for 100% completion, it can break a man.)

Graphics / Art Style: The graphics and animations aren't exceptional, but they get the job done, and most of the enemy designs are fun and inventive. (personal favourite being the gunslinger robots) 

Story: The story is the game's biggest weakpoint, it boils down to; big monster knocked the exp out of you, go hunt it down. If you enjoy rich, story driven games, this won't scratch that itch. (Though some of the character interactions are hilarious)

Gameplay: Battles make up the majority of EBF3's gameplay, and if you don't enjoy the combat the rest of the game will very quickly start to drag, but if you enjoy the JRPG turn based style, this should be a treat, with some great boss battles.
There are a number of parts in the game that serve no real purpose (mostly the minigames) except to gain a couple achievements.

Music: The music in this game is brilliant, and is easily one of the best points of the game. (Though again, personal taste will factor into your enjoyment)

Misc: There is a very big point that has to be made about this game before you get it. In terms of balance and fine-tuning, this game is all over the place, this isn't too obvious if you're playing on Normal, but on the higher difficulties it becomes pretty glaringly obvious.

Price: Obviously, the game is free, but unlike most free games on Steam, it's actually free. No Pay2Win, no microtransactions at all. Think of the game as a sort of Demo for the rest of the series.
The game's sequels, EBF4 and 5 are better than this game in almost every way, (Hence their actual pricetag) but this game serves perfectly as an introduction to the rest of the series, because it's free, you can play it and decide if you want to buy the sequel.

A really nice indie RPG. The battle system reminds me of some jRPG classics. There is a wide variety of enemies, each of them come with their own challenges. Skills are decently thought out - you need to find out how you want your team to work and use appropriate abilities to achieve that.
The bosses are a nightmare on epic difficulty, especially the last one. Your team will wipe a few time on most bosses (and monoliths) before you put together a strategy to defeat them. That's good - that's what epic difficulty is for.
One of the most likeable aspects of the game is its sense of humour. There are lots of references to pop culture, some slightly inappropriate jokes and some really nice easter eggs.
Last of all - it's free. The most You can lose is time, and that's what games are for, right?

56613069.review:
This is a game that truly blends nostalgia for turn based classic rpgs with tongue in cheek humor and isn't afraid to make fun of itself. With a surprisingly engaging elemental based battle system and various difficulty levels, Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a fun romp.

Pros:
Lots of hidden chests.
Lots of achievements that are fun to hunt down.
No wasted downtime due to movement healing between battles.
A solid challenge on the higher difficulties.
An interesting forge system to buff and unlock abilities in gear.
It's relatively old, but has aged pretty well.
New game+ included to help you hit some of the more challenging achievements.
Lots of silly / tongue in cheek humor (a pro to me, anyway)!
Great soundtrack, which is available as DLC for free or purchasable on Phyrnna's Bandcamp site.
Free! And worthy every penny. :p

Cons:
Normal difficulty is pretty easy for the first 2/3 of the game, but ramps up later.
Controls for some of the sub-games are frustrating and not modifiable. 

Overall, definitely worth playing if you like classic 16-bit era RPGs (that use flash sprite style graphics), or if you want some background on the characters before playing installments 4 and 5 of the series.

54346556.review:
No sabía que este juego estaba en Steam. Ha sido toda una sorpresa.
Pero mi mayor sorpresa no era ver que este juego estaba en Steam, sino que la franquicia está más viva que nunca cuando pensaba que había caído en el olvido.




Advierto que se viene tocho de los gordos, ya que este juego tiene un gran significado para mi.


En una época donde no existían los videojuegos F2P como Warframe o Fornite, los pobres nos buscábamos la vida navegando en Internet buscando juegos en Google. Época donde no tenías una consola de Nintendo o de Sega, pero tenías la Potato Master Race que solo corría el buscaminas y un juego de pinball de Windows que era el vicio padre.

Ahí es donde descubrí Minijuegos.com, una web española donde se publicaba una gran cantidad juegos flash (muchos de Newgrounds) con un pequeño resumen en español (aunque luego todos estaban en inglés).

¿Quién necesitaba una SNES teniendo el Super Mario Cutre-Flash en PC?
Muchas franquicias de videojuegos las descubrí gracias a esta web junto a muchas otras como Mundijuegos, Juegosarea y un largo etc...

También descubrí desde ahí grandes animaciones flash como Madness Combat o Super Mario Bros Z.



Entre muchos juegos de gran calidad como Strategy Defense, Traffic Slam, el juego del MacDonalds y, mi favorito, el Super Smash Flash, se encontraba Epic Battle Fantasy.

Epic Battle Fantasy empezó siendo un juego flash del mentón que su sistema de combate estaba totalmente inspirado en los antiguos Final Fantasy (del 1 al 6). Consistía en juego de rol por turnos el cual nos enfrentábamos a muchas oleadas de enemigos y un jefe antes de volver a la tienda a comprar pociones. Me acuerdo que el jefe final del juego era un "Goku zombi" y siempre intenté derrotarlo en dificultad Epic pero era imposible.

Epic Battle Fantasy 2 era su continuación, pero con mucha más personalidad. Esta vez ya contaba con música propia (en vez de música de Final Fantasy y similares) y diseñaron una historia. Matt y Natalie debían derrotar a un villano que resultó ser Lance y debían abrirse paso entre muchos enemigos, los cuales había nuevos y antiguos (como las babas, que son el icono del juego).

Y finalmente está Epic Battle Fantasy 3, que dejó de ser un juego solo de batallas por oleadas y pasó a tener una aventura dividida en un mapa con mucho contenido y exploración.
Me acuerdo que en su día, cuando era un crío, nunca llegaba hasta al final porque nunca se me guardaban los datos, ya que el juego lo jugaba online y no se guardaban datos en la red como pasa ahora con los juegos F2P. Es por eso que me alegré verlo en Steam donde si se guarda mi progreso.







Habiendo explicado todo eso, hablemos del juego.

El juego trata de unos tres personajes que son héroes y deben salvar el mundo de un poderoso villano llamado Akron. Durante el viaje se enfrentarán a poderosos monstruos que interrumpirán su camino, saquearán tesoros y forjarán sus armas y armaduras  para volverse los guerreros más poderosos.

Por lo genérica que es la trama, el juego no se toma en serio a si mismo e incluso los personajes se burlan de sus propios estereotipos. Es un juego que sabe reírse de si mismo y a la vez parodiar a otros juegos de su mismo género, así como animes y películas.



Hablemos de la jugabilidad:

Lo que me encanta de este juego es que es muy friendly con el jugador y aún así sigue siendo desafiante.
Cuando digo "friendly" me refiero a que el juego pone pocas penalizaciones y hacen el juego más cómodo y disfrutable. Por ejemplo, aquí no hay combates aleatorios: ves a los enemigos y peleas contra ellos cuando quieres y si quieres los ignoras. Habrá enemigos que te interrumpirán el camino, pero peleas contra ellos CUANDO TU QUIERES y no cuando el juego quiere.

Además, puedes abandonar cualquier combate sin ninguna penalización, incluso contra jefes, lo que permite un turno para analizar al jefe que te vas a enfrentar sin recibir daño y luego tranquilamente, fuera de combate, te cambias las armas y armaduras para tener ventaja contra este.


¿De que ventajas hablamos?
Al igual que los Epic Battle Fantasy anteriores, los enemigos tienen resistencias y debilidades a ciertos elementos, al igual que tus personajes según la armadura que lleven.

Es muy similar a los efectos y estados que hay en Pokemon, aunque se podrían comprar con muchos juegos de rol (si es que conociese alguno más con el que comparar directamente).



Por último, me gustaría hablar de algunos aspectos técnicos del juego.

No me voy a poner muy exigente porque hablamos de un juego hecho por una sola persona y está muy currado en todos los aspectos, aunque esto de que no se pueda poner a pantalla completa y tenga resolución de un juego de portátil quizás a más de uno no le acabe de gustar.

Aún así el juego de ve bien y además tiene una música muy buena, además de ciertos "efectos especiales" de los Limit Break que molan bastante (en especial el Kyun).






Resumen:

*LO BUENO
- Buen juego de rol por turnos.
- Mucho contenido y exploración.
- Buena historia.
- Buenos personajes.
- Buen humor.
- Muy friendly con el jugador.
- Muy fácil al principio y muy difícil al final.
- Muy divertido.
- Buena música.
- ES GRATIS Y SIN MICROPAGOS, A DESCARGAR YA!!!

*LO MALO (y no hay para tanto)
- Gráficos hechos por paint y a mala resolución. No tiene pantalla completa.
- No tiene contenido post-game.
- No está en español.


Dejando en claro todo esto, yo recomiendo a todo el mundo empezar la saga de Epic Fantasy Battle por este (el 1 y el 2 no están en Steam de lo simples que son, pero aún así los podéis buscar en Internet y probar, pero no son obligatorios).

Se trata de uno de estos juegos que no dejarán huella en la historia de los videojuegos, pero nos darán horas de diversión y unas cuantas risas aseguradas.



Por cierto, si no has leído todo lo que he escrito tranquilo, yo tampoco.

Mi relación con los textos tochos es directamente proporcional a la relación entre Matt y los rompecabezas.

47468089.review:
Extremely uninspired, stock turn based game with no meaningful structure.

Players walk around highly cramped and unimmersive maps, collecting droves of junk items and consumables while fighting back to back to back monotonous combat encounters. 



There does not seem to be any genuine story, just occasional idle conversation dialogue and computer character interactions. What dialogue there is, is mostly meaningless and lacks any form of passion or character design, it's just words on a screen. There really is not any humor, childish or not, it's just random whatever conversations that are trying to be zany but there's actually no joke or clever wording; it's just pointless nonsense dialogue.

The combat is stock turn based role playing fights. No innovation or intricacy or any form of divergence at all from the basic format which is generally just a damage race dressed up as strategy. No satisfaction to how it plays out or any level of purposeful effort to make it unique or appealing. Yet it is pretty much the entire game, meaningless combat encounter after meaningless combat encounter. Picking up numerous items, asinine fetch quests and having to factor in loads of strength and weakness statistics on enemies which all serve as filler for where actual dynamic gameplay mechanics would be.

The world gives no sense of immersion what with the confined scopeless maps with loud generic fantasy music sounding off at all times. The characters and world itself are just a jumble of whatever random juvenile ideas the developer could come up with, there is zero consistency to the world itself or its nature; and what is there is completely bland and typical. The computer characters are void of identity and the protagonists are just generic adolescent fantasy personas, as represented by the boring dialogue they have. And the computer characters are absolutely everywhere, as if you are meant to talk to all them multiple times to fill up the space where a real story or narrative would be. Yet none of them have anything interesting or enjoyable to say, the screenshots of them saying funny things account for a fraction of how many are actually in the game.


As a whole it just feels very much like the kind of thing an adolescent developer with a lot of time on their hands would come up with. A copy paste combat system in a world filled with incoherent juvenile fiction with no overarching vision to why any of this is happening or exists. This one may be free but its successors are not and by the looks of it they all are this exact same shallow format with mild advancements in between.

And apparently one of the characters can get an actual Nazi uniform as an outfit, which only reinforces the shallow tone of this whole thing.

47382566.review:
The resolution, style and UI navigation give away that this was originally a flash game from 2010. If this bothers you or you don't like cute things, this game might not be for you, but to everyone else I can strongly recommend this game.

Don't let the aforementioned aspects fool you - the gameplay in Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is extremely solid and despite the simple, easy to pick up turn-based battle system, there's a surprising amount of depth to it. There are no boring throwaway battles like in many RPGs, where you just have to spam normal attacks to win. Every fight requires thought and strategy - especially the boss fights (these can get pretty long, by the way). In general, the difficulty is well-balanced, always giving you a reasonable challenge without overdoing it. I played on Normal, but there are 4 levels of difficulty in total (Easy, Normal, Hard, Epic), which should cover just about every kind of challenge people could want from it.

The story takes a backseat as the game focuses on combat and a bit of exploration and sidequests. There are many secrets to discover and achievements to unlock, which actually allow you to discover even more secret areas within the game, so it's worth going for them. What story is there, though, is pretty cute and gets the job done.

There are only two frustrating experience I've made. One happened during the penultimate boss fight, where one part of the boss was poisoned, but just got healed by it every turn for the rest of the fight because he absorbed poison damage. There's no way to remove it anymore, as you can't use healing items on your enemies or damaging items on yourself (which would also come in handy, considering there's a skill that does more damage the less HP you have).
The other one is the accuracy system. Despite making sure to buff it during and outside of combat and reducing the enemies' evasion, my characters would still miss a lot in some areas.

These are small gripes though - I thoroughly enjoyed this game. My first playthrough took me about 12 hours, but that was at a very slow pace and while looking for secrets, so I'm sure most people will be faster. It's the kind of game that's perfect to play in one sitting on a comfy day off, and it's entirely free. Go give it a shot!

47237872.review:
Uno más que se une a esa larga fila de personas que también tuvo la dicha de haber conocido semejante juego en páginas de juegos flash, en mi caso, Newgrounds.

Debo decir que primeramente jugué al 4 antes que el 3 y cuando me enteré que ambos estaban también en Steam, realmente no dudé en empezar a descargar el 3 y tirarle dinero al 4 y fortuitamente, ahora también al 5

Este es un juego que se puede definir como un juego hecho con MUCHAS ganas y cariño que perfectamente puede enseñarle más de una cosa a los RPG´s actuales en casi todo y sin necesidad de ser sumamente extravagante, con historias ultra profundas, personajes principales impotantes y demás. 

Las peleas, aunque básicas y clásicas, están muy bien hechas con un sistema de combate que es simple, pero intuitivo como los primeros RPG´s con un sistema de ataque por turnos llevado a tiempos contemporaneos sin innovar mucho, sólo muestra acciones necesarias sin nada extra para molestar. Debe destacarse más que nada lo de las resistencias a elementos y los efectos de estado, tanto los positivos como negativos muy bien balanceados.

El dialogo es genial, aquí no verás largos textos de cada NPC contandote su vida, no. EBF lo que hace es reirse de esas cosas en ocasiones, rompiendo la cuarta pared cada que puede y haciendo mil y un referencias a series de anime y videojuegos de ROL tanto en sus textos como en sus NPC´s, la ropa, comida, habilidades, etc. Los textos son cortos, cargados de humor en su mayoría y están en todos lados para sacarte una risa si conoces un poco de videojuegos o anime. 
En las batallas son geniales, más los comentarios cada integrante cada que un compañero ''muere´´ o los que salen en esos momentos de puzzle.

Los gráficos, perfectos con el mundo que tenemos. Realmente me alegra ver que se mantiene la estética de cada personaje (sin ser Lance hasta el proximo juego con su ropa) va genial con lo que hace el juego de ser como un anime de aventura y comedia en el cual realmente los imaginaría así de ser un anime. Igualmente los enemigos que encima, antes de iniciar una batalla se ven como en esos juegos de Pokémon que antes de luchas con ellos se ven como  una versión entre pixelado y estilo anime.

La dificultad del juego es la que quieras, la mejor es la media ya que es la historia sin muchas complicaciones a excepción de uno que otro jefe, pero por lo demás, este juego busca ser jugado de forma tranquila para contarte la aventura de los 3 heroes, aunque igualmente si así lo deseas puedes subir esa dificultad hasta que se vuelve algo ... injusto, sólo por si deseas quebrarte la cabeza disfrutando las mecanicas de combate en vez de la historia.

Lo único que veo relevante para mirar algo confuso es la historia que bueh. En sí, no sé si decir si es una referencia al juego Cronno Chross y con su pelea contra el devorador del tiempo y de ahí el plot simple de la aventura, que para resumir la aventura y su fin sería algo como: Despertaron a un ente sellado casi indetenible que los derrotó fácilmente y que ahora sí o sí deben matar porque sino él destruirá todo lo que vea. De última puedes decir que pega con los personajes algo brutos y que el juego es más de comedia, aún así, se le puede perdonar ya que esta saga nunca trató de ser compleja historica ni argumentalmente.

En sí, EBF o más bien, toda la saga está hecha para disfrutar y jugar tranquilo, para divertirse con personajes graciosos que dicen y hacen cosas random por un fin que aunque este sea el de evitar la destrucción de todo, deja en claro que el objetivo real del juego es darte una historia divertida, pasarla bien y todo esto construido de forma solida bajo las viejas y cómodas mecanicas de los juegos RPG de antaño.

It was a fun turn-based battle RPG where you have to balance out who gets what skills, or which perma stat increasing item you give them. Sometimes, you'll be bombarded with debuffs, or your enemies will be constantly buffing other enemies and healing everyone. It didn't stop me from completing the game, but I had to grind longer than I wanted to, which caused enemies in the next area to be a hot knife through butter. Overall, it's a good experience if you're looking to follow the EBF series.

44890703.review: This game is the reason I play videogames this day. It was the first game I played that I really got into and it has aged quite well. The characters, while very simple, are all very charming. The humor is great, even if a bit offensive at times. The gameplay is really well made and quite challenging in the later areas. The soundtrack is also pretty damn good, with each theme fitting the different areas and situations. The character and enemy designs are also really charming, from cute bushes to ancient demonic deities. The whole games also looks really good, with an artstyle that portrays every kind of enemy really well. My only complaint would have to be the lack of post-game content, but that problem is completely fixed in EBF4. If you want a really good RPG to play, I would suggest this one. You can also play the earlier flash games (Epic Battle Fantasy 1&2) in the series if you want, although those don't follow the usual RPG formula and are moreso just waves of mostly unrelated enemies continuously appearing and are not nearly as polished as this one. And if you like this one, you could buy EBF4 and the soon to come EBF5 here on Steam or, if you don't want to spend the money, the entire series is free-to-play as flash games, though there is a lot of extra content in the Steam versions of EBF4&5 and quite a bit in this on as well, even though it's free. Final Verdict: play it. It's a great timewaster for casual players and Epic Difficulty is a decent challenge for the ones who like that sort of thing.

43633595.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is an excellent little flash game done by the great Matt Rozack, and the whole game's a treat. It's an obvious, never-apologetic spoof of classic Final Fantasy, but better in quite a few ways.

The gameplay is a pure classic JRPG: turn-based, heroes first, cast your buffs, hit your limit breaks and wipe the field. EBF is a bit different in the approaches it takes: anything that annoyed you about other classic RPGs is gone here, everything is very streamlined and satisfying, and if it isn't, the game will mercilessly mock it. No random encounters, or "chance to fail" when fleeing fights. Characters share EXP, but you upgrade their abilities seperately, and can even decide who gets which skill if you want to build one as a tank, one as a healer, etc.

The game's music is surprisingly impeccable; I even bought one of the tracks. It looks very fine, especially for a flash game, and the creator has certainly found their style. The second element of what most puts this title above the rest is the script: the characters each have great charm, and funny moments abound. The game is never above kicking through the fourth wall to mock game mechanics, and the characters themselves make fun of the more annoying aspects. While much of the script may come off as a joke that only gets you the first time, I'd still highly recommend it just off the dialogue scenes.

One of the few issues the game has is duration. There are only three characters to play as, although they will each really catch your ear the whole time. It's rather short, for an RPG, but still has some decent runtime. If nothing else, the game still has longer modes, such as a survival mode (if I remember), and the achievements/optional bosses will hold your attention well. EBF 3 is another treasure of a flash game making it to the bigger-time, and I'd recommend it to any JRPG fan. 8.5/10.

Some decent features I'd like to see in more rpg's like your gear changing your appearance, I also liked the idle animations where characters would read or listen to music while waiting for their turns.
Walking around regens your HP and MP so you don't have to continously waste items, and status effects end after the fight.

Neutral:
A lot of references, I saw quite a few characters from shows I've seen and I assume there are alot more, but I already figured a great deal of them were flying under my radar since I don't remember characters from anime that well.
The music was decent but seemed to be one song per area so I was getting sick of them really fast.

Cons:
Animation and art style is flash game level, skill effects were weak.
Even in the short bit I played I could tell the game was going to be grindy, items made to cost thousands of gold, skills that cost hundreds of points, and enemies quickly climbing in health. You also get waves of enemies in some fights. So the combat started feeling more like a clicker game where enemies just become better damage sponges requiring more time to kill than any real challenge in how you use your skills.
Story wasn't really engaging. Even though I didn't see much of it I didn't like the bit I saw. You're 3 ,apparently, OP adventurers and you get reset to lvl 0 because you poke a demon that syphons your powers. I don't know why but rapid loss of powers in order to continue the plot bothers me.
Probably belongs with grindy but the quest system was crap, there's no way to tell which npc will have a quest so it expects you to talk to all of them. Every quest I ran into was just to gather specific items and bring them back, these may be pretty spread out too since I didn't finish a single one and therefore don't know what the rewards for finishing them are.

Despite giving it a No, the game is free so definitely check it out if your interested. I just didn't feel like playing any longer after my first session personally.

43316082.review:
I've played this game every couple years since it came out. I was quite happy with it in its previous incarnations; but the current version on steam has several annoyances. My critique involves specifically the Steam version of the game.
 * Some enemies, while still not difficult, are immune to all skills. This makes you grind them extremely slowly with melee attacks (as literally every single skill except "attack" and "cleave" are considered "magic", as is the Poison status effect!)
 * The game seems laggier for some reason
 * Several balance changes make the game easier/slower. Enemies are less weak to poison
 * These changes combined with a nerf to the most difficult boss fight makes that fight several times easier by comparison
 * Massive nerf to mini-games; while allowing you to quickly bypass them; means you'll probably play them once. Due to the way medals work in this game, this buffs your characters directly due to the gear they can receive with substantially less effort on the players' part. While I'd agree they're the worst part of the game, it used to actually be a choice to simply skip those medals and move on or put in the effort to unlock more chests. 

I highly recommend the browser based version of this game if you can find it before the 2016 update, but can't recommend this one given that the better version exists. It's still quite playable, but why play a worse version of the game?

Otherwise:
 * The game is quite balanced damage wise and when playing on Hard or Epic; you can win but only if played very well.
 * Due to the way gear is stat'd, it takes sophistication to arrange your resistances and tradeoffs to both damage and skills (I consider this good balance)
 * Skill progressions are enjoyable
 * Lots of skills to choose from and most of them are not useless even in the 4th act; and probably half of them are still adequate or good for the remainder of the game. 
 * Hidden loot that requires wandering around is always a plus for me

42959450.review:
I played the game on whimpy Easy mode so consider all the info below with that in mind. (I'm too old and ornery for a mode any more challenging than that).

Fun, cute, colorful!  There's something very gratuitously satisfying about seeing HUGE numbers and flashy effects being splashed around during a fight.  I think there's a plot in there somewhere but who cares when nothing but mahem is happening on the screen.  I had a blast. The gameplay is very smooth, never had a hitch or slow-down with all that was going on.  I accidentally got a few achievements while playing but wasn't really paying attention. It was only when I closed the game did I notice them.  A good number of them are pretty funny...(pig molester???...OMG!!!...I'm a pig molestor...lol..). 

I didn't bother with the side-quests/mini-games so can't comment on those exept to say this:  I dislike games that include mini-games that MUST BE COMPLETED IN ORDER TO FINISH THE GAME.  Bleh... If I wanted a different type of gameplay, such as a FPS, a puzzle or a timed game I would buy that instead.  Fortunately, I could skip them as none were necessary to complete the game. I think there is an achievement for doing a certain number of them.

Random points smooshed together:

The gameplay is turn-based. There are three preset characters: a fighter, a magic user and a dexer-type.  They seem well-balanced. In a fight, the order of the characters always starts out the same: Melee with magic enhancement, a healer/fighting-magic user and a ninja with magic enhancement. There is no way to switch their order around [b]when not in a fight[/b].  During a fight the order goes back to normal after the switched character finishes his/her move. (I write about this later in more detail). All three characters use mana to perform their usual and special moves.  No matter how tough a weapon is, without using magic, every weapon is puny--might as well throw uncooked macaroni at the enemy. (Come to think of it, that might be fun.)

There are tons of spells and melee abilities with a few special spells given to each character reminding me of my Final Fantasy days when I would strike with an all-powerful one-time-use death spell. In this game when the SPECIAL is cast, the character who casts it becomes useless, (uses up all mana). He can strike with a plain weapon for [I]several[/I] turns until mana is slooowly built back up.  There are foods and spells that can fully restore his mana so he'll be ready at his next turn but whichever character gives him help will lose their turn. 'Scan' and a couple of the healer's special moves use up only a small amount of mana.  If I remember to, more on scanning later..

Characters can escape the fight during their turn with no penalties, even during a boss fight.  When [I]running[/I] from a fight, the team comes back fully healed with all statuses, such as poison, instantly gone.  When a fight is complete statuses will be removed in a few seconds and waiting a bit longer will slowly heal the team without needing to use healing items or spells. Monster's don't attack first--the characters have to walk close to a monster icon and hit the space bar to initiate the fight.  A monster blocking a path needs to be killed before the team can get by.  Using a waypoint crystal will reset the areas already completed but any monsters blocking a path before will not respawn.  The rest will respawn which is useful if you feel you're not quite tough enough for the next area.

I found the waypoint/recall crystals very confusing.  They are crystals set on an object like a rock that are difficult to see in the world.  Once you click on the first one, located in the first town, you will fall for a ways down and land in an area with the other waypoints you'll find later in the game.  The others will be inactive until you locate and click on them in their own area.  Pay attention to what they look like because some are very hard to spot in the world.  You'll notice, though, that they seem to match the area they're located in. Example: The one in the snowy area is all white, is covered in snow with a white crystal on top.

There are very minimal amounts of armors and weapons but what there are can be upgraded with adds you win after victories, from completing side-quests, what you find in chests, from NPCs, or secret areas.  I find this feature a lot easier than trying to hold on to tons of sets of armors/weapons/spells/adds/tools/food on the off chance I might need them later.  Your characters don't have a backpack, per se, but can access all their goodies from the character menus in between and in fights ala the RPGs of old.  (This game first came out in August, 2010...it's old but not ancient and holds up remarkably well!)  

What seems to build up in the menu are the items NPCs need for their quests.  A plus is the items can also be used by your characters.  If your character uses an item you find later a quest giver needs...don't worry, more of that item will come by another source in the game.  Once you pick up a quest try to keep in mind what that quest giver looks like and location.  There are so many NPCs with quests when you finally get all the items one of them needs, its a matter of "Now where did I see that guy...???!!"  No NPC looks like the other and are usually found in a crowd of other NPCs who are also handing out quests.  You have a Quests menu you can click on. It shows a picture of the quest giver but all of them are facing forward.  Not so in the game...they could be facing any direction, any angle, in front of or behind something.  The only thing that kept me doing the quests was some of the rewards were very useful, (including quest items for other quest givers).

There are the usual areas to fight in: forest, ocean/beach, ice, desert and volanic.  The body types of monsters are reused ad nauseum but with different colors, effects and abilities, (such as a creature in the an ice area weak to fire is now found in the volcanic area with fire spells but weak to ice).  Occasionally, the game will mix up the two in one fight creating more of a challenge.  Example: You reach an ice area, and, anticipating the area you're in, you gear up with fire weapons and ice armor.  But...surprise!  You're in a fight with both fire and ice monsters at the same time--and for giggles and grins a weaker mini-boss-type is thrown in the mix with weaknesses & abilities unlike the others.  [spoiler]Good adivce:  keep investing in dark magic for spells and adds.  Earth-based magic also got me out of a lot of jams. Lightning-based magic was very useful in the first part of the game.  For the rest of the game it was useless here--great there.[/spoiler] 

About scanning and more non sequiturs: 

If you so wish, the game will keep you busy with the achievements, mini-games, secrets, and some areas entered only after a certain amount of medals are won, tasks from NPCs and scanning. The ninja can 'scan' monsters, (once for each monster type), to discover a monster's weaknesses, resistences, abilities, and useful stats, but he can only scan during a fight.  After a monster is scanned a bright spot with a (?) appears near the monster's head for all three characters to see.  [spoiler][I]When a fight is triggered[/I] and seeing a monster the ninja hasn't scanned yet, I find it's a good idea to choose the "switch-the-fighting-order" icon between the fighter and the ninja. The icon is found on all three characters' menus--very useful ability since the characters' lineups are static.  Switching the character's fighting order will allow the ninja to scan the monster before any aggression has occurred.  He can only scan one monster at a time in each turn then his turn is over.[/spoiler]  Other than bosses, I can't recall a fight where my team didn't throw the first punch.  Game is a solid 8/10

I bought 3 & 4 bundled together.  I'm hoping for the same fun with game 4!

42792821.review:
In short - Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a great game. In Epic Battle Fantasy 3 (EBF3) you play as three diffrent characters - Matt the warrior, Lance the gunner, and Natalie the mage/healer. You travel through the varied world to defeat the dark entity Akron. In your travels you come across many people, who may have quests for you, and monsters, who you most likely have to defeat.

Its gamplay is simple, yet enjoyable, as in combat you scan your foes to identify their weaknesses, and then use that information to carry out your turn, limited by the equips and elements that each of your characters can attack with.

The game has a great soudtrack and this is one of the few games that you can complete, and without going to far out of your way, you can 100% the achievements.

There are four dificulties in EBF3:
[b]Easy[/b] — where you can walk through enemies, vary little will give you any trouble.
[b]Normal[/b] —  as it says - normal.
[b]Hard[/b] —  Difficult, you need to pay more attention to equips, defense status, etc.
[b]Epic[/b] — Much more difficult, expect to lose at least once, if not more, you need to pay attension to every detail and plan ahead.

On top of all of that it is free, so if you don't like it, you won't have lost anything, so you may as well give it a try.

 gave you..Very nice..

 Where Easy can almost be blasted through as Epic makes think of your battle strategy a bit longer..You forge and use the 
 equpment that is resistant..For example Ice or Death etc..
-New Game +..The level cap of 30 can be removed and yuou can keep almost everything..

  This is more like 32 bit graphic game..Just as note for those who are expecting something massive..

40842160.review:
EBF3 is a fun, albeit basic, RPG in the old-school style of games like Chrono Trigger. There's not much of a story here, but the characters interact well with each other. It's funny to see the game make commentary on traditional RPG roles. Like how the hypermasculine warrior characters are offset by the party's hyperfeminine magic user who is also vegan.

My only major gripe is that there's no real reward for completing all achievements. I completed the game without using any Stat boosting items, apart from equipment upgrades. Once you finally unlock the last chest area, what you receive in return is just more of the same Stat boosts. Presumably to make the game easier on subsequent playthroughs.

All in all, this is a game that most turn-based RPG enthusiasts can appreciate.

40276560.review:
Such a nice nostalgia bomb to when I used to play this on Kongregate.

Without going very in-depth, everything about the game is just great. The story is really simple and straightforward, the characters are likable, the enemies are really cool (especially the final boss), all the skills are actually useful for the most part at least in some parts of the game. Even the music is really nice. The attention to detail is very nice too, the detail being able to jiggle Natalie's tiddies in almost every occasion.

Though I have criticize the equipment. You get all these cool armors, hats and weapons, only to never have any use to some, if not most, of them, because at that point you're better off using just the weapon that's best against most of the monsters of that map. With 5 maps and more than double the weapons per character, some weapons are simply not going to get the love they deserve. Same goes for the armor as well.

And while the monsters are cool for the most part, I do wish at least the bosses would stand out a little more. Jack is very forgettable, especially for being the first boss. Squid's gimmick is that it has 2 tentacles that it can regenerate which really is nothing. The mammoth is literally just a goddamn mammoth, it doesn't have anything special other than being able to ram you with tiny mammoths. And the tank just has some runes which for the most part don't do anything special besides one stuns and another heals. At this point the monoliths, golems, worms and zombie dragon all have more personality than those bosses do.

As a side note, monoliths gave me cancer so I'm suing Matt for the medical treatment.

TL; DR: Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a great RPG throwback with an extremely solid battle system and tons of character. Since it’s 100% free I would recommend this if you’re into RPGs and can look past a few weirder things said and done. 

I used to play this a game a ton on Armour Games when I was younger, but I never got around to finishing it. I haven’t finished the game on Epic yet but I still feel I have a good grasp for a representative review and I will update this review if anything noteworthy during my epic playthrough.

First, I’ll start off with the differences from this version from the online version. The steam version (and updated Kongregate version) haven’t changed much from the original, it’s mostly just balancing changes, which is definitely appreciated, but nothing huge.

From Epic Battle Fantasy 1 and 2, 3 is by far the biggest jump in scale, going from a fixed path of battle them immediately another battle and then a shop every so often, EBF 3 changes a lot from 1 and 2 going to a very open game, like a more traditional RPG which benefits almost everything in my opinion and Matt did a great job in doing it so well.

The story is ok, it continues on from the last instalment, in which (Spoiler->) [spoiler] Matt and Natalie join up with Lance at the end [/spoiler]. The story starts off with the characters basically getting rekt by a literal god, losing all their powers and equipment and ending up in a small town. They then set off to try and take it down. You really don’t need to have played the last two games to play this one, combat is largely the same and still isn’t too complex, but still allows for a lot of strategy and you’re not missing out that much in terms of story.

The fact that this also made by mostly 2 people: Matt Roszak (who was doing the coding, artwork, animation etc.) and Phyrrna (previously known as HalcyonicFalconX) (who did the music) is really impressive especially when you realise how much attention to detail has gone in (not to mention it’s free). The music done by Phyrrna is great and I can see why is got a physical soundtrack release.

The artwork, animation and overall aesthetics are unique (In a good way) and make the game very distinguishable in that aspect, and the music complements it very well. In battle is where you’ll see the most detail, outside still does have detail but it’s more like a sketch in terms of how it looks, some people will like it but others won’t, it’s down to preference. The UI is really intuitive, both inside and outside of battle (although it’s a bit excessive on comic sans).

The combat is one of the best things about the game for me personally. There is a huge amount of moves to unlock, use and upgrade along with all sorts of armour which you can mix or match to suit your preferred style of play best.

On your team you have three team members:

Matt who is the tank who primarily focuses on strong physical attacks over magical attacks and his attacks are usually on only one enemy.

Natalie is the mage and medic able to deal strong magical damage to lots of foes or just singular ones to concentrate the damage. She also has the ability to do a variety of healing moves but she has the lowest HP, defence, and attack of any character.

And finally, Lance who is the new character added to the third EBF. He’s pretty well balanced and can deal physical and magical damage to one, all or attack mostly one enemy with one third of damage going to any other enemies. He also has a couple rarer elemental attacks such as bomb and he has a decent healing move. He is also the character with the almost vital move; scan, which lets you see the enemies HP (in more detail than just a bar), what it’s weak and resistant to, along with any other useful information.

Each attack also has a unique animation so the really strong attacks both look like and do a serious amount of damage. There’s not much grinding required, I am basing this review of a normal playthrough and as long as I went for the extra chests which involved usually fighting more, grinding isn’t that big of a deal and you can get away without doing much at all if any. But If you play on hard and especially Epic you will have to grind to get to level 30 (The highest achievable level in normal play) for the last fight, but that’s kind of expected for really high difficulty levels.

As for the bad:

-Some of the achievements.

-NoLegs is a bit too talkative.

-The squid is just weird.

As for more serious bad things:

-I know this is a nit-pick but there are a couple of achievements basically there to embarrass you, you can always just ignore them obviously but It’s a bit annoying if you want to get all achievements, it’s a small complaint and it might have just been me and it shouldn’t sway you not to get the game, but it did make me hesitate as to go for all achievements. 

-There are multiple instant death moves and although they don’t appear often, have low accuracy and most of the time you have time to syphon them before, sometimes you can’t and it can lead to some pretty cheap feeling deaths.

- Some of the things said and done by the characters and enemies feel a little out of place, some of the things Lance says especially makes me sometimes wonder if this game is trying to be more serious yet the rest of the game is relatively light-hearted.

- The squid is generally really weird.

Overall however, if you can look past some of the weirder things said and done and you’re into RPGs I think you’ll enjoy this game. 

It’s also free.

38311703.review:
The title is right about one thing, this game is EPIC!

3 Players to play as, all with their own supporting role and strategies.

Multiple elements and weaknesses.. and even status effects too.

There's tons of equipment, with each one being able to upgrade to Level 5 with the right materials (dropped by enemies, hidden treasure chests in the overworld, or even completing quests!)

There's alot of quests that are actually pretty useful and not that difficult, some even grant you hidden moves for you to learn.

The overworld is nice, and charming. Minigames can be fun but sometimes stressful.

The combat itself can be very complex at first due to having so many options and all 3 characters at the start.. but you will get used to it fairly soon.

The game's bonus content is suprisingly large, with alot of cool concept art and even FAN art, also the AMAZING soundtrack. There's alot of medals to get, and if you have enough you can unlock hidden rooms with even more equipment.

This game normally can take around 10-20 hours to beat, depending how you play. There's 4 difficulty modes, Easy, Normal, Hard, and Epic.

Once you get into later battles, you really have to think and not just spam attacks hoping for the best. Elemental weaknesses are very important. 

The Final Boss in my opinion is a huge step-up difficulty, with me getting my first game-over on it, I pray for those souls who play on Epic.

Overall, this is a very fun and charming RPG game. While the story is quite generic and doesn't really have much of a plot, it's still a great RPG game to play. If you thought this game was good, you should try EBF4, and soon awaits an upcoming EBF5.

This game is free, and the soundtrack is too! I reccomend this game, it's a fun little series.

8.5/10

38085338.review:
Epic Battle Fantasy 3 is a playable, heartfelt love letter to the JRPGs of yesteryear. Anyone who grew up playing the budding RPGs of the SNES and PS1 eras will be very comfortable here.

Moreover, EBF3 actually goes so far as to actually be a [i]functional game[/i], as opposed to just an pseudo-interactive roller coaster that parody/reference games tend to be. There's a surprisingly well-thought-out JRPG combat system in EBF3, which I know isn't saying a whole lot (given how simplistic JRPG combat tends to be), but it's still good nonetheless.

If I had one criticism, it's that you can't really play it with a gamepad. Menu selections are done with the mouse and are in varying screen positions, so a simple JoyToKey setup won't work. A [i]complex[/i] setup might, but that's too much effort.

However, I saved the best for last. The best part is that it's absolutely free. So what are you waiting for?
